awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Biomechanical Movement Baselining Technology Suite for Wearable Technology and Stretch Sensor-based Validation of Lower Body Characteristics
awd_abstract_narration:
Human performance engineering at Mississippi State University, conducted by a large, interdisciplinary team, representing diverse researchers and practitioners in academics, athletics, & industry, develops and validates wearable technologies that can be used to capture human movement in realistic environments. Testing in labs is critical for knowledge advancement. The instrument suite consists of state-of-the-art Gait Real-time Analysis Interactive Lab (GRAIL) system and surface electromyography (sEMG) sensors for human performance assessment. The broader impacts of the projects arising with use of the proposed technology suite will increase research capacity and permit the crossing of scalability barriers for current wearable technology prototypes developed through the human performance engineering research and development program. This human performance laboratory suite will empower interdisciplinary researchers to advance the health and welfare of the American public through new types of wearable technology solutions and technology validation. The success of such research will enhance existing partnerships between MSU and athletic, industrial, military, and medical partners while further growing the infrastructure for research and education with an interdisciplinary focus.

The acquired system build supports research of the human performance engineering team, including a project entitled “From the Ground Up – Using Soft Robotic Sensors (SRS) to Create a Foot and Ankle Wearable that Accurately Captures Real-time, Kinematic and Kinetic Data During Athletic Training” by extending the capability of current instrumentation. The combined GRAIL and sEMG system provides a more accurate, convenient, and safe platform for the generation of large data sets, especially with clinically at-risk populations. Activities enabled by the instrument suite advance transformative research within the field of human factors engineering by validating Soft Robotic Sensors (SRS) as a motion capture tool for all lower limb segments in the human body. The instrument suite will allow for more control and repeatability during participant testing of complex, dynamic movements (gait, slip/trip perturbations), and will enable a much faster data collection process, allowing the research team to properly utilize state-of-the-art deep learning approaches requiring large amounts of data. Secondary transformative research areas include: (1) Gait-based disabilities in pediatrics, (2) Chronic ankle instability, (3) fall prevention, (4) fatigue and unsafe behavior identification systems, and (5) autonomous vehicles including pedestrians and their behaviors around autonomy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Human performance engineering at Mississippi State University (MSU), conducted by a large, interdisciplinary team representing diverse researchers and practitioners in academics, athletics, & industry, develops and validates wearable technologies that can be used to capture human movement in realistic environments. Testing in labs is critical for knowledge advancement. Through this project, an instrument suite was purchased and installed in the Athlete Engineering Research Laboratory (AERL) at MSU. The instrument suite consists of a state-of-the-art Gait Real-time Analysis Interactive Lab (GRAIL) system and surface electromyography (sEMG) sensors for human performance assessment.

The AERL research team completed four training workshops on the new instrument suite and two GRAIL workshops for 60 practitioners who attended MSU’s 2024 Athlete Engineering Summit. Throughout the project, 54 tours were hosted to introduce various communities to the technology. Visitors included collaborators from regional industries, military installations, educational institutions, and research laboratories.

A system was developed for equitable scheduling and use of the instrument suite. Any collaborators within MSU and the local community can coordinate with the lab to utilize the GRAIL with one of the currently certified operators. The lab utilizes Microsoft Bookings to book times with the GRAIL that fit the availability of anyone with the appropriate training. The lab offers pilot data collection to interested users external to AERL at no cost.

For this instrumentation grant, dissemination of results includes (1) introducing the technology to communities of interest and (2) facilitating the use of the instrumentation for research across diverse academic disciplines.  First, through tours and workshops, the technology has been introduced and demonstrated to potential users from various academic disciplines (e.g., engineering, science, communications, kinesiology) and varied industry and government organizations. Using the GRAIL, our team collaborates with MSU athletic training staff to investigate student-athlete recovery needs. Our team has developed custom protocols specific to the needs of the athletic trainers. Second, the GRAIL has been used for multiple research projects, including projects with extramural funding and student-led projects.

The intellectual merit of this project is demonstrated through the advances in product validation, data processing, and human factors engineering. The combined GRAIL and sEMG systems provide a more accurate, convenient, and safe platform for generating large data sets, especially with clinically at-risk populations. Activities enabled by the instrument suite advance transformative research in human factors engineering by validating Soft Robotic Sensors (SRS) as a motion capture tool for all lower limb segments in the human body. The instrument suite allows for more control and repeatability during participant testing of complex, dynamic movements. It will enable a much faster data collection process, allowing the research team to properly utilize state-of-the-art deep learning approaches requiring large amounts of data. Secondary transformative research areas include (1) Gait-based disabilities in pediatrics, (2) Chronic ankle instability, (3) fall prevention, (4) fatigue and unsafe behavior identification systems, and (5) autonomous vehicles, including pedestrians and their behaviors around autonomy.

The project's broader impacts arise with the use of the proposed technology suite, which will increase research capacity and permit the crossing of scalability barriers for current wearable technology prototypes developed through the human performance engineering research and development program. This human performance laboratory suite will empower interdisciplinary researchers to advance the health and welfare of the American public through new types of wearable technology solutions and technology validation. The success of such research will enhance existing partnerships between MSU and athletic, industrial, military, and medical partners while further growing the infrastructure for research and education with an interdisciplinary focus. Finally, through tours and outreach activities, the project increases the visibility of STEM careers and research to K-12 students.


Last Modified: 12/20/2024
Modified by: Lesley Strawderman
